_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Mammoth Pacific has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan to address California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, ?2735-2785) in June 1999. Mammoth Pacific is extremely diligent in the handling of isobutane and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Mammoth Pacific staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using isobutane for geothermal power production.
Mammoth Pacific has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Isobutane System.  Mammoth Pacific?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of isobutane. 
    Stationary Source and Regulated Subsnce:
Mammoth Pacific?s geothermal power production facility is fueled by geothermal brine from nearby Casa Diablo Hot Springs, located in Mammoth Lakes, California, approximately 5 miles east of the City of Mammoth Lakes and 0.5 miles east of State Route 395. The area around the facility is rugged and generally uninhabited. The facility uses isobutane as a binary working fluid in a Rankine cycle for power production. There are a total of three plants in the facility: G1 (Mammoth Pacific I, MP I); built in 1984, and plant G2 (Mammoth Pacific II, MP II) and G3 (Pacific Lighting Energy Systems I, PLES I), built in 1990.  
Mammoth Pacific Limited Partnership is a partnership between Ormat and Constellation Energy Group. The facility utilizes hot geothermal brine as a energy source in a binary Rankine cycle with isobutane as the working fluid. Thermal energy from the brine is transferred to the isobutane as it is vaporized, pressurized, compressed, and cooled

in a power cycle. The electricity generated by this process is then sold to Southern California Edison.
The site is currently operated by Mammoth Pacific staff and is manned 24 hrs a day. The facility employs approximately 21 personnel.
The regulated substance managed at the Facility is isobutane. Isobutane participates in a closed-loop power cycle, traveling through accumulators, compressors, heat exchangers, turbines, and condensers in order to produce electricity. The maximum intended inventory is 526,500 lbs of isobutane, the majority of which is contained in the isobutane accumulators. 
    Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Anasis:
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for each of the two geothermal power production systems.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab 2 of the CalARP Submittal Binder.
Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Two alternative release scenarios were modeled. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab 2 of the CalARP Submittal Binder.
Risk Considerations
Although the use of isobutane has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Mammoth Pacific has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the vapor cloud explosion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics o

f the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an isobutane release:
?    Automatic / Manual Shutdown
?    Well Designed Relief System
?    Perimeter Deluge System
The history of the Mammoth Pacific facility (i.e., no CalARP-applicable isobutane releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Isobutane System.
    Accidental Release Prevention Progm:
As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the Mammoth Pacific facility  to manage process safety issues associated with the use of isobutane for the isobutane system.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.
The facility?s maximum intended inventory of isobutane is 526,500 lbs.  Therefore, the covered process has over the 10,000 lbs threshold quantity for EPA RMP and Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantities.  As a result, the isobutane covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3 and Cal/OSHA PSM.
The Isobutane Prevention Program 3 elements include:
?    Process Safety Information
?    Process Hazard Analysis
?    Operating Procedures
?    Training
?    Mechanical Integrity
?    Management of Change
?    Pre-Startup Safety Review
?    Compliance Audits
?    Incident Investigation
?    Employee Participation
?    Hot Work Permit
?    Contractors
In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergency Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.
    Five-Year Accident Hisry:
There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of isobutane at the Mammoth Pacific facility in the past five years.
    Emergency Response Progm:
Mammoth Pacific staff are not First Responders.  Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Mammoth Pacific will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. Mammoth Pacific has filed a Business Emergency Plan

to help coordinate with local responders.
An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 ?3220 is in place.
    External Events Analysis Informatn:
Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, ?2745.7(q); the following external events analysis information shall be submitted:  
    The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.  
o    During the June 2009 PHA a broad list of external events was considered by the Team.  General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of isobutane were addressed.  The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, vehicle impact and landslide.
    The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed. 
    The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team. Currently, a seismic assessment is scheduled for August 2009.
    For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply 
1)    The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;
2)    Major hazards identified;
3)    Process controls in use;
4)    Mitigation systems in use;
5)    Monitoring and detection systems in use; and,
6)    Changes since the last Hazard Review (HR) or PHA
    Refer to Section 7.4 of the RMP*Submit Printout for the required PHA information.

talled and maintained as designed.
    The most recent field verification of equipment was conducted on 04/23/2009.
    Planned Changes To Improve Sety:
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the June 3, 2009 PHA Report.  Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by December 2009.
